s.text: The fit was nice and loose, the way my wife likes it.
While much of men's and women's clothing is designed to send out a complex code of sexual and social signals, Slates, true to their name, are blank.

The makeup counter was lined with female forms: an older Latin woman painting the wide-open eyes of an African-American teen-ager; a white girl and a pink girl and a brown girl crowding around the eyeliner counter, avidly seeking their "one true color" amid the promiscuous riot of magenta, peach, chartreuse, fuchsia, and mauve.

--comprising guys who have gained 50 pounds since high school, guys who know their way around a search engine but, what with the wife and the child support and the gas bills and all those $7 bottles of wine, lack the loose dollars and idle time that can buy true American style.
If the people who sell Slates are so dumb and I'm so smart, how come I ain't rich like them?
If the people who sell Slates are so dumb and I'm so smart, how come I ain't rich like them?
What is it about modern life (I wondered idly) that makes entrepreneurs want to celebrate and sell its micro-ness?
There it was again, an island of Slates, dull as dirt but not as cheap: two pairs for $100.
There it was again, an island of Slates, dull as dirt but not as cheap: two pairs for $100.

My search for Slates, apparently an act of free will, was but a pawn's move in the great game of advertising played by casually superior types on Madison Avenue and in Hollywood (and in Redmond, Wash.
Suddenly, I was face to face with one of the recurring nightmares of bourgeois life.
I wanted to follow her asking playful questions.
I wanted to follow her asking playful questions.
I wanted to follow her asking playful questions.
I wanted to follow her asking playful questions.
